meaning_mnemonic:
Something is <kanji>versus</kanji> the <kanji>outside</kanji>. Back in the day, everything was a battle with the outside. You had the Mongols... the rebels... and the foreigners. So, when you say something is "versus the outside" you're just saying it's something compared to where you are right now. It's something that's <vocabulary>foreign</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>external</vocabulary>.

This is a formal word typically used at the beginning of compounds to indicate that the subject is related to foreign affairs, such as 対外政策 (foreign policy) or 対外貿易 (foreign trade).

You <kanji>exit</kanji> a <kanji>facility</kanji>. It's your <vocabulary>release from prison</vocabulary>!

出所 commonly refers to leaving or being released from facilities ending in 所, particularly 刑務所 (prisons). It can also be a slightly formal word for <vocabulary>source</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>origin</vocabulary>, often used in discussions of copyright to specify the origin of cited information, images, or content.
A <kanji>time</kanji> <kanji>limit</kanji> is a <vocabulary>time limit</vocabulary>, but not any old time limit. This is usually used at the beginning of compound words, especially 時限爆弾 (time bomb).

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>return</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to return</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to return something</vocabulary>. You know you're doing the action of returning someone or something because when you do, they just <reading>sue</reading> (す) you because you broke the thing you were supposed to return before returning it.
A trade (貿易) company (会社) is a company that makes a lot of trades, because it's easy for them, making this word a <vocabulary>trading firm</vocabulary>.
If 遺伝 is <kanji>heredity</kanji> and you pass your heredity to your <kanji>child</kanji>, how is it being passed? Via <vocabulary>genes</vocabulary>, of course.
Remember <kanji>Nara</kanji> (奈良)? This is the <kanji>prefecture</kanji> of it, making it <vocabulary>Nara Prefecture</vocabulary>.
廃止 is <kanji>abolition</kanji>, so the verb version of that would be <vocabulary>to abolish</vocabulary>.

You have <kanji>ride</kanji> and <kanji>exchange</kanji>, so you take your ride (bus, train, whatever) and exchange to another bus, train, or whatever. That's why this word means <vocabulary>to transfer</vocabulary>, and most commonly <vocabulary>to change trains</vocabulary>.
If 指摘 is "pointing out" then the verb version is <vocabulary>to point out</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>open sea</kanji> <kanji>rope</kanji> is the rope that attaches <vocabulary>Okinawa</vocabulary> to the mainland.
To "do maintenance (維持)" is keeping something in that maintained position, which is <vocabulary>to maintain</vocabulary>.
You know <kanji>Meiji</kanji>, (明治), and you know <kanji>restoration</kanji> (維新). Combine them together and you have the <vocabulary>Meiji Restoration</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>dance</kanji> of going to <kanji>see</kanji> someone. It's a <vocabulary>sympathy visit</vocabulary>. Because, you know, you gotta dance the dance of sympathy.

A dancing (舞踏) <kanji>meet</kanji> is when you all get together to do dancing, the kind that's like "step step swing" (or whatever). This is a <vocabulary>ball</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>dance</vocabulary>.
一般 is "general" and "common", and adding 的 just gives you <vocabulary>ordinary</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>general</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>common</vocabulary>.

<kanji>All</kanji> <kanji>general</kanji>-<kanji>al</kanji>! It's super general. It's <vocabulary>general</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>overall</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>across the board</vocabulary>. Nothing specific going on here.
To 頼む is "to ask for" or "to request." The noun version of that is <vocabulary>a favor</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>a request</vocabulary>.

頼む is "to ask for" or "to request." This word is <vocabulary>to rely on</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to trust</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to depend on</vocabulary>. You know it is this word because it is <reading>ru</reading>de to rely on your friends, but you are anyways.

You already know that 依頼 means "request." What's a "request" <kanji>person</kanji>? It's someone who requests things from you. In other words, your <vocabulary>client</vocabulary>!

依頼人 generally refers to someone requesting particular services or assistance. Whether it's consulting a lawyer, employing a detective, or initiating a bank transfer, they're the one making the request.
馬鹿 is "stupid" so if you hear a rumor about something (らしい) that's stupid, you'll just respond by saying "that's <vocabulary>absurd</vocabulary>."
You <kanji>demand</kanji> and <kanji>need</kanji> this thing, which is why you must make this <vocabulary>demand</vocabulary>.

I have <kanji>certain</kanji> <kanji>demand</kanji>s for <kanji>goods</kanji> to take on this trip. Don't worry, it's just the <vocabulary>necessities</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>essentials</vocabulary>.

必需品 is a relatively formal word that refers to items that are necessary for daily life, survival, or specific activities.
Your <kanji>year</kanji> <kanji>age</kanji> is the number of <vocabulary>years old</vocabulary> you are.
<kanji>Someone</kanji> of <kanji>tall</kanji> <kanji>age</kanji> is going to be an <vocabulary>elderly person</vocabulary> or an <vocabulary>old person</vocabulary>.
If you are at an <kanji>elderly</kanji> <kanji>age</kanji> you are at an <vocabulary>old age</vocabulary>.

You send your <kanji>best regards</kanji> to everyone. Is this <vocabulary>good</vocabulary>? Is it <vocabulary>okay?</vocabulary> Is it <vocabulary>all right</vocabulary>? Yes, of course, how nice of you.
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>spin</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to spin</vocabulary>.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>avoid</kanji> or <kanji>dodge</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to avoid</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to dodge</vocabulary>!
<kanji>Dodge</kanji> a <kanji>difficult</kanji> situation by getting away from it. Do an <vocabulary>evacuation</vocabulary> to get out of there!
I <kanji>dodge</kanji>d being <kanji>pregnant</kanji>. Whew. Good thing I was taking my <vocabulary>birth control</vocabulary>.
To do <kanji>pregnant</kanji> <kanji>pregnant</kanji> is <vocabulary>to be pregnant</vocabulary>.

A <kanji>pregnant</kanji> <kanji>lady</kanji> is a <vocabulary>pregnant woman</vocabulary>. How simple is that!

妊婦 is a relatively formal term used to refer to a woman who is pregnant. In casual situations it's common to add さん and say 妊婦さん, to make it sound friendlier.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>do</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to do</vocabulary>. This is a polite way to say "to do."
You do <kanji>one</kanji> <kanji>do</kanji> and I'll do another do. I'll do the same thing <vocabulary>to match</vocabulary> it.
Somebody <kanji>do</kanji>ing you <kanji>fate</kanji> <kanji>-al</kanji> would... probably be pretty <vocabulary>fatal</vocabulary>!
The <kanji>morning</kanji> <kanji>edition</kanji> is the <vocabulary>morning edition</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>moon</kanji> <kanji>edition</kanji> is the <vocabulary>monthly edition</vocabulary>, since 月 also means "month."
The <kanji>evening</kanji> <kanji>edition</kanji> is the <vocabulary>evening edition</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>edition</kanji> will <kanji>go</kanji> out to the public if we were <vocabulary>to publish</vocabulary> it.
The <kanji>day</kanji>'s <kanji>edition</kanji> is the <vocabulary>daily edition</vocabulary>.
<kanji>Play music</kanji> that will give me <kanji>comfort</kanji>, why then I should go see a <vocabulary>musical performance</vocabulary> to keep me nice and calm.
If you <kanji>perform</kanji> and <kanji>play music</kanji> you are doing a <vocabulary>musical performance</vocabulary>.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>accompany</kanji>, so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to accompany</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be accompanied by</vocabulary>.

This word is both transitive and intransitive. So it works both when bringing someone with you, like 助手を伴って来る (to come with an assistant), or when going along with someone else, like 上司に伴って行く (to go with one's boss). When it's about physically accompanying someone, it's often used together with a movement verb.

伴う is also used figuratively to talk about consequences that tend <vocabulary>to go hand in hand with</vocabulary> something, like 変化にはリスクが伴う (change comes with risk). In this case, 伴う is usually used by itself.

meanings.meaning: To Go Hand In Hand With

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>same</kanji> <kanji>accompany</kanji> means you are in the same place as someone, and you are accompanying them. This word means <vocabulary>to accompany</vocabulary>. This is only used for accompanying people.

<kanji>Join</kanji> and <kanji>join</kanji> with each other. This is an <vocabulary>annexation</vocabulary>, or a <vocabulary>merger</vocabulary>.

併合 generally means that one entity absorbs or incorporates another entity, often implying a dominant or controlling role by one of the parties.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>lean</kanji>, and the verb vocab version means <vocabulary>to be leaned</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be tilted</vocabulary>. You aren't doing the leaning or the tilting, though, you're just watching, which is why you say "cool" (く) when you see it, because it's already done.
If you usually <kanji>lean</kanji> <kanji>yonder</kanji>, in that direction, that will be your <vocabulary>tendency</vocabulary>.

The kanji means <kanji>contrary</kanji>, and this is the adverb version of that, so it means <vocabulary>on the contrary</vocabulary>.

却って is a common expression used when something brings the opposite result from what you expected, like "I tried to help, but <vocabulary>instead</vocabulary> it made things worse." The kanji version is formal, so you'll often see it in kana as かえって, especially in casual writing.
It is <kanji>contrary</kanji> to what I think is good. It is <kanji>below</kanji> my standards. Thus, <vocabulary>rejection</vocabulary>.

Something that is in the <kanji>interior</kanji> of something else is inside of it, deep, and <vocabulary>far back</vocabulary> / <vocabulary>in the back</vocabulary>. Just imagine something interior to something else, it's probably in the back.

The <kanji>interior</kanji> person (the honorific さん shows it's a person) is the person who stands in the interior of the house and doesn't leave, making that person your <vocabulary>wife</vocabulary>. Ouch. Sexist kanji strikes again.

A <kanji>far</kanji> <kanji>consider</kanji> is when you let your considerations go far from you so you don't think about how angry you are about what's going on in front of you. It allows you to have some <vocabulary>restraint</vocabulary>, since your considerations are far from here. It also allows you to <vocabulary>decline</vocabulary> things, since you're not considering the other person's feelings.

If you <kanji>distribute</kanji> your <kanji>consider</kanji>s, you will be giving <vocabulary>consideration</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>care</vocabulary> to whatever you're distributing these cares to.
I'll <kanji>think</kanji> and <kanji>consider</kanji> this. I'll give it <vocabulary>consideration</vocabulary>.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>suspend</kanji>, but in this case, you're going to suspend your win or loss and try <vocabulary>to stake</vocabulary> it all on one, big bet. You're going <vocabulary>to risk</vocabulary> it all!
Go ahead and <kanji>suspend</kanji> <kanji>fate</kanji>, let's get this done before the time we are fated to do it. We are that <vocabulary>eager</vocabulary> to get started.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
A <kanji>cool</kanji> <kanji>cluster</kanji> is something that has a cluster of cool-creating coolant. This device is <vocabulary>air conditioning</vocabulary>.

A <kanji>warm</kanji> <kanji>cluster</kanji> is when you get a bunch of warmth together, and then use it to warm your home. This is indoor <vocabulary>heating</vocabulary>, kind of like the same way how an air conditioner is a "cool cluster."
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>handle</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to handle</vocabulary>.
I want to <kanji>suppress</kanji> and <kanji>pressure</kanji> you! Muahaha! This is <vocabulary>oppression</vocabulary>.
Try to <kanji>suppress</kanji> and <kanji>control</kanji> the enemy. We must <vocabulary>control</vocabulary> them.
This is going to <kanji>suppress</kanji> and <kanji>stop</kanji> what's coming at you. It's a <vocabulary>deterrent</vocabulary>.
<kanji>Choose</kanji> and <kanji>select</kanji> your choice. This is your <vocabulary>selection</vocabulary>.
<kanji>Draw</kanji> a <kanji>copy</kanji> of the world and you are making a <vocabulary>depiction</vocabulary> of the world.

If you <kanji>draw</kanji> an <kanji>image</kanji>, you end up with a <vocabulary>drawing</vocabulary> (or a <vocabulary>painting</vocabulary>).

描画 is a relatively formal word that refers to the process of creating pictures (rather than the pictures themselves). This includes not only painting or drawing but also digitally creating images on a computer screen.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>draw</kanji> and the verb vocab refers to creating visual art, like drawings or paintings, making this <vocabulary>to draw</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to paint</vocabulary>. It can also be used figuratively <vocabulary>to illustrate</vocabulary> ideas or dreams, or <vocabulary>to depict</vocabulary> scenes in one's mind.

The kanji and the word are the same! This word also means <vocabulary>board</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>disc</vocabulary>, which makes sense if you think about it. Boards you play games on are basically just trays for the pieces, and discs go inside boards (like records) for storage.
A <kanji>round</kanji> <kanji>tray</kanji> is a <vocabulary>disk</vocabulary>, though if it goes through the air it becomes a <vocabulary>flying saucer</vocabulary>.

A <kanji>foundation</kanji> <kanji>tray</kanji> is a flat thing that is your foundation. It holds everything up. It is the <vocabulary>base</vocabulary> of everything that goes above it. It is the <vocabulary>foundation</vocabulary>.
If you <kanji>versus</kanji> (compare) the <kanji>title</kanji> of these two things, you'll notice that they're the same as each other. They have <vocabulary>symmetry</vocabulary>.

A <kanji>temporary</kanji> <kanji>title</kanji> is what you give something when you don't have a final title for it. it's a <vocabulary>working name</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>tentative name</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>one</kanji> <kanji>person</kanji> <kanji>title</kanji> is the title one person gives themselves. They are speaking in the <vocabulary>first person</vocabulary>.

<kanji>One</kanji> <kanji>cord</kanji> is enough to tie you <vocabulary>together</vocabulary> with someone. Imagine an invisible cord stretching between you and the people you do things together with. That one cord is like a symbol of your togetherness. Very poetic (or very Death Stranding), right?

Keep information <kanji>inside</kanji> a <kanji>cord</kanji> that cordons off just you and a few others (or maybe no one else). Only the people you let inside the cord can know, because it's a <vocabulary>secret</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>confidential</vocabulary>.
This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>loose</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>loose</vocabulary>.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>loose</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to loosen</vocabulary>. This is when something loosens on its own, and not via your actions. You know this because a cow is loosening things, <reading>moo</reading> (む)...
This is the na-adjective version of <kanji>loose</kanji>, so that means this word means <vocabulary>loose</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>mild</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>gentle</vocabulary>.
To the <kanji>committee</kanji> I would like to <kanji>consign</kanji> these things. This is what I <vocabulary>consign</vocabulary>.
If you <kanji>consign</kanji> something to someone, you are going <vocabulary>to entrust</vocabulary> them with that item. Here you go, I entrust you.
If you <kanji>believe</kanji> you can <kanji>consign</kanji> your trust to someone, then you can <vocabulary>trust</vocabulary> them, or you are being <vocabulary>entrusting</vocabulary>.

You <kanji>accept</kanji> and <kanji>consign</kanji> the job. You are going to <vocabulary>be entrusted with</vocabulary> this property for the winter. Don't go into room 237.

受託 is a formal word that means taking on a task someone has entrusted to you. You'll often see it in business contexts to talk about a company taking on work from another, like 業務を受託する (to <vocabulary>undertake</vocabulary> contract work). In legal contexts, it can also refer to being entrusted with physical items or money.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>presents</kanji> so if you do presents, you're giving them, making this <vocabulary>to give a present</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to gift</vocabulary>.

贈る is used for the act of giving when it's done with particular thoughtfulness or sincerity — often to express things like gratitude, love, congratulations, or respect. Things you might 贈る include flowers on a birthday, a commemorative item at an event, or even words of thanks. It can also extend to bestowing honors, titles, ranks, or awards, as these are also "gifts" in a sense.
The <kanji>presents</kanji> you <kanji>acquire</kanji> are a <kanji>bribe</kanji>. What? That is <vocabulary>bribery</vocabulary>!
A <kanji>bribe</kanji> <kanji>bribe</kanji> is a <vocabulary>bribe</vocabulary>.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>bribe</kanji>, but when you pay a bribe, you are going <vocabulary>to pay</vocabulary> something or <vocabulary>to cover</vocabulary> something, like a meal, or something like that.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>escape</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to escape</vocabulary>. Also, it can be <vocabulary>to flee</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to run away</vocabulary>. Basically, if you're trying to get away from someone or something, you could be doing this.

逃げる is a general word for escaping that can be used in any situation, from running away from danger, to avoiding responsibility, to simply leaving a place quickly.
If you <kanji>escape</kanji> <kanji>death</kanji> you have, well, an <vocabulary>escape</vocabulary>.

We got <kanji>life</kanji> by <kanji>sending back</kanji> our runner to home plate. That run allowed us more life in this game. Now, maybe we'll win! It was all by <vocabulary>reaching home plate</vocabulary>. Outside of baseball, this means <vocabulary>returning alive</vocabulary> from somewhere.
If we <kanji>return</kanji> and <kanji>send back</kanji> things, we will have done a <vocabulary>return</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>restoration</vocabulary>.

<kanji>Send back</kanji> to the <kanji>origin</kanji> means you are going to <vocabulary>give something back</vocabulary>. This word is commonly used to mean "giving benefits back to the consumers.” For example, if a company makes more money than usual, they can thank consumers with a 利益還元 sale, lowering prices to "give back" some of the profits.

In the context of chemistry, 還元 also means <vocabulary>reduction</vocabulary>, like reducing an oxidized substance back to its original, unoxidized form.
豆腐 is <kanji>tofu</kanji>, and 湯 means <kanji>hot water</kanji>, making it tofu you've put in hot water, aka <vocabulary>boiled tofu</vocabulary>.

If 伸びる is "to be stretched" then 伸ばす is <vocabulary>to stretch something</vocabulary>, where you're doing the stretching. You know this because you took a <reading>bus</reading> and you stretched it out to be an even longer bus.

If you have <kanji>reach</kanji>, that means you're able <vocabulary>to exert</vocabulary> a great influence on people. Watch out, though, because it also means you're able <vocabulary>to cause</vocabulary> great harm.

及ぶ means "to reach" or "to amount to." The noun version is more like a grammar thing, as it means "<vocabulary>as well as</vocabulary>." Perhaps if you are reaching a certain point or certain amount, then you are adding things on. That's why this means "as well as".

Note that 及び is a term usually used in formal writing.

踏む is "to step on" and the kanji 込 means <kanji>into</kanji>, so this means <vocabulary>to step into</vocabulary>.

踏み込む means to step further and harder than usual, like stepping forward to lunge for a ball or stepping hard on the accelerator. Figuratively, it can also mean <vocabulary>to intrude</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to delve into</vocabulary>, like stepping into someone's house without permission or exploring complex topics one step further.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>ultra</kanji> or <kanji>super</kanji> so the verb version is what happens when you do something ultra or super much. You start <vocabulary>to exceed</vocabulary> the amount you were meant to do it. If you ultra drive a car, you exceed the speed limit. If you ultra study, you exceed your brain capacity. Get it?

Take your <kanji>rope</kanji> and <kanji>stretch</kanji> it out to show where the cutoff is. This is when you <vocabulary>rope off</vocabulary> something. It shows your <vocabulary>territory</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>turf</vocabulary>. Don't cross this rope I've stretched out, it's my <vocabulary>domain</vocabulary>.

The <kanji>fee</kanji> for <kanji>fragrance</kanji> and <kanji>spicy</kanji> in your food is the fee of <vocabulary>spices</vocabulary>. If you don't pay your spices fee, you aren't going to have any spice or fragrance in your food. If you do, you'll have those things and your food will be awesome!

A <kanji>spicy</kanji> <kanji>hug</kanji> is a hug that feels not so great. But, it's not really painful all at once, either. As you're receiving a spicy hug, you just have to show <vocabulary>patience</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>endurance</vocabulary> while it lasts.
If your <kanji>interior</kanji> is <kanji>deep</kanji>, then you're a really <vocabulary>profound</vocabulary> person.
When you <kanji>lack</kanji> <kanji>stretch</kanji>ing, your body has to get that energy out somehow, so you end up <vocabulary>yawning</vocabulary>.

Remember how you learned that 馬鹿 means "idiot?" Well put two idiots together and everything they say and do is absolutely <vocabulary>absurd</vocabulary>. Remember how <vocabulary>ridiculous</vocabulary> that "Dumb and Dumber" movie was? Yeah. Like that.

You already learned that 漬ける means "to pickle something," so if you add that to the end of a food word (and leave off the る) it means that food has been <vocabulary>pickled in</vocabulary> something, like  酢漬け  (pickled in vinegar).

Something is in the <kanji>interior</kanji> AND the <kanji>bottom</kanji>? Why, it's in the very <vocabulary>depths</vocabulary>! And if it's in the interior and bottom of you, then it's at the <vocabulary>bottom</vocabulary> of your heart!
The kanji and the word are exactly the same.
Your <kanji>knee</kanji>'s <kanji>head</kanji> is the <vocabulary>kneecap</vocabulary>. It's also called the <vocabulary>patella</vocabulary>, if you want to get fancy and talk about bone names.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>bite</kanji> or <kanji>chew</kanji> so the verb version is <vocabulary>to bite</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to chew</vocabulary>.

A <kanji>perfect</kanji> <kanji>disc</kanji> is <vocabulary>flawless</vocabulary>. It's just <vocabulary>perfect</vocabulary>. 

As you may already know, in Japan the symbol ⭕ is used to mark correct answers. See how it looks like a perfect disc?

The main <kanji>reason</kanji> behind your <kanji>connection</kanji> to some people is your <vocabulary>lineage</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>history</vocabulary>. Lineage and history tie people (especially families) together.

This word can be used for people with a prestigious family lineage as well as for historic buildings, especially temples and shrines.
You're looking at <kanji>heaven</kanji>'s <kanji>river</kanji>, or the river of heaven. There's only one river in heaven (i.e., the sky), and that's the <vocabulary>Milky Way</vocabulary>!

The kanji is <kanji>fry</kanji>. You already know the verb for "to fry" (炒める), so this verb is for a slightly different cooking technique — <vocabulary>to roast</vocabulary>. 

So what's the difference between the two? Generally speaking, 炒める involves the use of hot fat or oil, while 炒る describes a way of cooking that involves less or no oil or fat, often to dry roast things. For example, you'd use 炒める for making fried noodles or fried rice, and 炒る for roasting sesame seeds or beans.

You know the kanji means <kanji>eat</kanji>, and you also already know 食べる. So what's the deal with this also meaning <vocabulary>to eat</vocabulary>? 

食う carries a more masculine and coarse tone than 食べる, so it can come off as rough or impolite in certain situations. It also has a wider set of usages, for example in saying that something is eating up time or resources, or saying that you were bitten by a bug. You'll come across more of these, but they're all pretty straightforward, so don't worry!

The <kanji>ordinal number prefix</kanji> <kanji>one</kanji> <kanji>bullet</kanji> is actually the <vocabulary>first installment</vocabulary> of something. Picture someone firing a gun to let everyone know that, yes, this is indeed the <vocabulary>first round</vocabulary> of… whatever you're doing.

Note that this is quite similar to 第一段. While 第一段 refers to the first phase or step within one larger, continuous process or structure, 第一弾 is used to refer to the first installment or part of a series of events or releases.
